content.webTitle: Sundance 2019: Ocasio-Cortez doc and Ted Bundy biopic headline festival

fields.headline: Sundance 2019: Ocasio-Cortez doc and Ted Bundy biopic headline festival
fields.bodyText: Documentaries on Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Roy Cohn and Harvey Weinstein will sit alongside dramatic features starring Zac Efron, Emma Thompson and Jake Gyllenhaal at next year’s Sundance film festival. The announcement of the full lineup promises the most diverse festival to date. Across the four competition categories, 42% of directors are women, 39% are people of colour and 23% identify as LGBT. Within the documentary strand lies Knock Down the House, a look at the movement of four female insurgent candidates challenging incumbents during the recent midterm elections, including Ocasio-Cortez. It sits alongside Where’s My Roy Cohn?, a look at the “dark arts” of the influential lawyer and his connection to Donald Trump, as well as Untouchable, the inside story of the rise and fall of Harvey Weinstein. There are also a number of films with a political bent, including the Steven Soderbergh-produced thriller The Report, the story of Daniel Jones, lead investigator for the Senate’s study into the CIA’s detention and interrogation program. The film stars Adam Driver, Jon Hamm and Annette Bening as Dianne Feinstein. The story of the British intelligence whistleblower Katharine Gun will also be brought to the festival in Official Secrets starring Keira Knightley. Gun leaked a top-secret NSA memo before the 2003 Iraq invasion that showed officials proposing the blackmail of other states to vote for war. The festival will also see the premiere of The Infiltrators, a drama about a group of undocumented youths who infiltrate a shadowy for-profit detention centre. One of the most buzzed about films to launch in January is the Ted Bundy drama Extremely Wicked, Shockingly Evil and Vile from the Emmy-winning documentary film-maker Joe Berlinger. It stars Zac Efron as the killer but will be told through the viewpoint of his girlfriend Liz, played by Lily Collins. “It doesn’t really glorify Ted Bundy,” Efron said earlier this year. “He wasn’t a person to be glorified. It simply tells a story and sort of how the world was able to be charmed over by this guy who was notoriously evil and the vexing position that so many people were put in, the world was put in. It was fun to go and experiment in that realm of reality.” Other big names set to grace Park City, Utah include Emma Thompson, who stars as a late-night talkshow host in Late Night opposite Mindy Kaling; Julianne Moore and Michelle Williams, who headline the comedy After the Wedding; Viola Davis, who will appear in a 70s-set coming of age drama Troupe Zero; Jake Gyllenhaal, who re-teams with his Nightcrawler director Tony Gilroy for the art world thriller Velvet Buzzsaw; and fresh from her Oscar-buzzed role in The Favourite, Olivia Colman will head to Sundance with a role in snake-handling church drama Them That Follow. Bend it Like Beckham director Gurinder Chadha will also premiere her 80s-set coming-of-age musical comedy Blinded by the Light about a teenager finding his voice with the help of Bruce Springsteen’s music. “Having been at the [Sundance] lab as a writer, being a mentor at the directors lab and now having the world premiere here of Blinded by the Light, a film that took eight years in the making, means the world to me,” she said of the film that received Springsteen’s blessing. “At a time when the world has so many divisive voices, Sundance offers us the greatest home to deliver our movie and its message of oneness to the world.” Traditionally, Sundance has become a major launching pad for smaller films, with last year’s festival hosting premieres for Hereditary, Eighth Grade and Sorry to Bother You. Next year’s festival will take place from 24 January to 3 February.
